Row.Text: A pirate code of conduct seems a contradiction, but here it stands, drafted, ready for ratification by a council of pirates. “Bit thin,” remarks a haggard old seafarer. “Could use some more notes,” says another.
Scribes have worked for years to refine the Code. It stands now on wrinkled vellum – a monument to pirate solidarity. “Bit thick,” remarks the old sailor. “Too long to read,” says another.
The Norman sailors fancy themselves sea dogs, scourges of the waters. The pirates cannot abide another laying claim to their domain.
Ensure that the seas remain under the black flag.
Sea dogs can bark all they want, but they remain on land.
The Five Hundred Lords of the Chola Empire are merchant kings, draped in gold and jewels, their names synonymous with wealth and luxury. Today, one has walked the plank. How many Lords are left?
Four Hundred and Ninety-Nine Lords meet Four Hundred and Ninety-Nine Swords.
Use a Buccaneer's "Raiding Party" action against the Chola.
The Lost Treasure of the Ming
The purser paces the length of the captured Ming vessel. After going over the numbers again and again, she reaches a conclusion: a sizeable part of the treasure has gone missing.
It comes out of the captain’s share.

The initial reports come in: a ship, laden with wealth, en route to pirate harbors. But as the weeks turn to months with no ship, the plans for spending this wealth turn to grumbles. Eventually, a captain returns – the ship, he claims, is in another’s hands.
The bosun of the treasure fleet surrenders along with the rest of the crew. With a sigh of exasperation, he signals that the pirate flag be flown from the mast. Again.
A good lashing will ensure this does not happen again.
Another treasure fleet has gone missing, another sack of excuses given at admiralty headquarters. The admiral looks at the captain suspiciously. “Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice…”
“Shame on me.” Seize the captain’s assets.
Black Sails on the High Seas
Over the seas, the pirates reign. They come from all nations of the world, speaking every tongue known to humanity, all with one overriding goal:

The workers on distant sites toil tirelessly in the sun, gleaning treasures from the land, treasures snatched, taken up, and loaded on ships bound for the motherland. In turn, these treasure ships are halted, boarded, and their goods taken up and bound for the Republic of Pirates.
The profits shall inspire new crews.
Workers, like sailors, deserve a share.

Those pirates who remember the Republic of antiquity have formed a new center of power in the new, distant settlement. They declare that it will be a city different from all others – a place entirely free of chains and shackles – of both mind and body.
Declare it the island of the free!

The Orang Laut – a group once within the Majapahit Empire, and now in the Republic of Pirates – spend their entire lives on the sea. Homes rock with the waves, residents fish from their docks, and children seem just as at ease in the sea as on the land.
They shall pilot the fishing fleet.
Dr. Rizal on the Open Sea

Though no stranger to ships, Dr. Rizal feels uneasy on the deck of the pirate sloop. Violence seems to simmer under the surface, and each of these sailors has a gallows waiting for them in some foreign port.
Befriend one. They might cut the doctor in on some loot.
A rare chance to see them in action!
The Found Treasure of the Ming
As workmen tear up the remnants of an old pirate inn, under the flooboards they discover a trove of plundered Ming valuables.
The treasures shall grace a museum of the pirate age.

Underneath an old wharf, construction workers find an enormous stash of gold – treasure pilfered from the old Republic of Pirates. The loot is of historical importance, but also is raw bullion that could feed {1_Civilization_Adj} coffers.
Sell it and feed the income to the treasury.
It is a window into the golden era of pirates!
